qas.question: What is unique about the method used for assention allowed by the Royal Assent Act 1967?

answers.text: does not require both houses to meet jointly

qas.question: How is assent granted under the Royal Assent Act 1967?

answers.text: by the sovereign in writing, by means of letters patent, that are presented to the presiding officer of each house of parliament

qas.question: Which document formats the letters patent?

answers.text: The Crown Office (Forms and Proclamations Rules) Order 1992

qas.question: In which year were minor amendments made to the Crown Office Order?
In the Royal Assent Act 1968, royal assent can be granted how?
The presiding officer makes an informal statement to whom?
Which method requires both houses to meet jointly?
Which act allows the sovereign to grant assent verbally?

context: Under the <b7_0>Royal Assent Act 1967<b7_0/>, royal assent can be granted <a1_0><b4_0>by the sovereign in writing<b4_0/>, by means of letters patent, that are presented to the presiding officer of each house of parliament<a1_0/>. Then, the presiding officer makes a formal, but simple statement to the <b5_0>house<b5_0/>, acquainting each house that royal assent has been granted to the acts mentioned. Thus, unlike the granting of royal assent by the monarch in person or by Royal Commissioners, the method created by the <b6_0>Royal Assent Act 1967<b6_0/> <a0_0>does not require both houses to meet jointly<a0_0/> for the purpose of receiving the notice of royal assent. The standard text of the letters patent is set out in <a2_0>The Crown Office (Forms and Proclamations Rules) Order 1992<a2_0/>, with minor amendments in <a3_0>2000<a3_0/>. In practice this remains the standard method, a fact that is belied by the wording of the letters patent for the appointment of the Royal Commissioners and by the wording of the letters patent for the granting of royal assent in writing under the 1967 Act ("... And forasmuch as We cannot at this time be present in the Higher House of Our said Parliament being the accustomed place for giving Our Royal Assent...").
